Subject: Re: [neat] Re: ANN: SharpNEAT Release (15-August-2004) + Phased searching
 experiment write-
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=127853030
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

Hi Ken,

>These are excellent and insightful observations.  Have you 
>considered getting a Ph.D? :P  Seriously, that is good research 
>getting to the bottom of these questions.
>  
>
Ahh shucks, well it's very kind of you to say so. Yeh I have toyed with 
the idea of going back to university, I guess I'd need to do an MSc or 
something before a Phd - and it just so happens there is a decent course 
practically on my doorstep at Birmingham. Perhaps I'll look into it a 
bit further, check out the implications, etc. Trouble is you see the IT 
job market is pretty buoyant in the UK so there's [potentially] quite a 
few opportunities there also. hmm.

>I think your proposed changes to SharpNEAT make good sense.  I also 
>do not kill off the top species, so I came to the same conclusion.  
>  
>
Yeh, and you still get to search through varied topologies because of 
speciation. It's just that in a worse case scenario a large proportion 
of the population (the best species) could be stuck in a local optima 
until one of the other species finds a better solution.

>But the idea of only adding a % of excess and disjoint genes I am 
>unsure about.  If a complex of genes has formed that are all 
>interdependent, that could be a bad move.  Maybe safer would be to 
>just make adding *all* the excess and disjoint genes probabilistic.  
>  
>
Good point.

>On the other hand, the real question of how to do it can only be 
>addressed through comparisons of the types you've been doing, i.e. 
>runs with one method vs. runs with another.  
>  
>
I suspect results will vary depending on the problem domain. e.g. the 
simple-ocr domain will probably benefit from inheriting single 
connections because it doesn't require any complex arrangement of 
connections, quite often a single connection between a pixel input and 
an output has an immediate beneficial effect, later additions of more 
single connections can then refine the solution further.

But simple-ocr is probably un-characteristically simple in that respect, 
so as a hunch I would expect your suggestion of "all or nothing" 
inheritance to be the better technique in general.

>It seems though that the most important conclusion so far is that 
>phasing is a very good idea.  But it would be good to get more 
>results backing that up so we can be confident about it.
>  
>
Yeh, I'll be going back over some of the other problem domains already 
implemented in SharpNEAT to see if the positive results seen so far can 
be duplicated.


Colin.
